Award.AwardTitle: Refractory Metal Doped Gallium Oxide Sensors for Extreme Environmental Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal # 1509653
Abstract Title: Refractory metal doped gallium oxide sensors for extreme environment applications

Abstract

Nontechnical:

Currently, an enormous amount of interest exists in the research and development of combustion processes for energy harvesting. Recent analysis shows that by improving coal-based firing/combustion processes in power plants, a cost saving of up to $409 million a year can be achieved. However, in order for this savings and efficiency improvements to occur, sensors and controls capable of withstanding extreme environments such as high temperatures, highly corrosive atmospheres, and high pressures are in critical demand. Besides the economic benefits of reduced costs, controlled combustion can also eliminate the pollutant emissions that are critically impacting our environment, health and energy resources. Optimization of the combustion processes in power generation systems can be achieved by sensing, monitoring and control of oxygen, which is a measure of the completeness of the process and can lead to enhanced efficiency and reduced greenhouse gas emissions. However, despite the fact that there exists a very high demand for advanced sensors for combustion monitoring and control in power generation systems and automobiles, the existing oxygen sensing technologies suffer from poor response and recovery times as well as long-term stability.

Technical:
The proposed project is intended to investigate the high-temperature oxygen sensors operational to temperatures greater than 700 degrees Celsius in a corrosive atmosphere for application in power generation systems. The overall objective of the research project is to investigate nanostructured gallium oxide (Ga2O3) based sensors for oxygen sensing, where we propose to conduct in-depth exploration of the role of refractory metals (RM) for doping the gallium oxide to enhance the sensitivity, selectivity, stability (3S) criteria) and reliability of such sensors while at the same time keeping device cost economical. The ultimate objective is to design oxygen sensors that combine rapid response, criteria, reliability, and robustness at extreme environments. Specifically, we will focus on engineering the nanostructured Ga2O3 with controlled dopants. The project work will be mainly directed towards fabricating the nanostructured W-Ga2O3, Mo-Ga2O3 and W-Mo-Ga2O3 sensors and gaining a fundamental understanding of dopant-induced structure-composition-electronic property changes on the oxygen sensor performance. The emphasis is to understand changes in the electronic structure of RM-incorporated Ga2O3 sensor as a result of interaction with oxygen. The obvious goal is to study the chemical reactivity of W-Ga2O3, Mo-Ga2O3 and W-Mo-Ga2O3 sensors and quantify the changes in electronic structure so as to derive a structure-property-performance correlation. The proposed study will provide a better understanding of the nanoscale phenomena, adsorption/desorption processes at nanoscale, and size-dependent reactivity to optimize the conditions to enhance the 3S criteria of the oxygen sensors in addition to response time. The results on the nanostructured W-Ga2O3, Mo-Ga2O3 and W-Mo-Ga2O3 sensors are expected to offer exciting opportunities to design and fabricate oxygen sensors with superior performance compared to the existing ones. The project success will, thus, potentially transform the sensor technology and will have a substantial impact on the investigators and students at the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP), a Hispanic serving minority institution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sensors that can operate in extreme environments can find utilization in automation, homeland security, aerospace, transportation, healthcare, and energy and manufacturing industries. The extreme environments, which often include high temperature, high radiation, thermal gradient extremes, high pressures and toxic chemical environments, place a stringent requirement on the sensor materials and architecture for reliable operation. Specifically, the current capabilities of oxygen sensor technology for energy and automotive industries are limited in terms of operating temperatures, poisoning effects and most importantly poor response time. This project work proposed using refractory metal incorporation into Ga2O3 to enhance the sensor performance for harsh environment applications. The central theme of the proposed research was to gain an insightful understanding of the structure-property-processing relationship in refractory metal-doped Ga2O3, which can help in understanding the role of dopants on micro- and nanostructure, which can help establish strategies to optimize the sensor performance. The results obtained and findings of this project work offered means to optimize the oxygen sensor performance operating at extreme environments. Existing knowledge on designing the sensors operating higher temperatures is limited in terms of finding novel materials that can dramatically improve the performance, especially the selectivity and response time, while the functionality retained at extreme environment conditions. In this context, the project substantially contributed to the advancement in the field by allowing the investigators to derive fundamental knowledge and understand the theory of the role of refractory metals into oxide matrix to design next generation sensors. We believe that the approach and lessons learned may be applicable to a large class of sensor materials for extreme environment applications. The project work demonstrated an approach to design materials based on nanostructured metal-doped Ga2O3, which exhibits a rapid response and excellent stability for oxygen sensing at elevated temperatures. Specifically, nanocrystalline b-Ga2O3 films with 4-5 at% W or Ti significantly improves the response time (~20 times) while retaining the stability and repeatability in addition to enhancement in the sensitivity of Ga2O3 to oxygen. These extreme environment oxygen sensors with a rapid response time and sensitivity represent key advancement for integration into combustion systems for efficient energy conversion and emission reduction so as to keep our environment clean and safe.The project outcomes may likely have substantial impact in the cross-disciplines of Electrical Engineering, Materials Engineering, Physics, Chemistry, Mechanical Engineering and Energy Science and Engineering. The principles learned from refractory-metal incorporation into Ga2O3 may be useful to further explore the options for designing novel ceramics and sensors for various applications. Furthermore, the underlying science and fundamental mechanisms may serve the basis for designing novel sensors for bio- and health- related applications.

The project provided excellent opportunities for underrepresented minorities (URM) in science and engineering. Mr. Ernesto Rubio was recruited and provided an opportunity to pursue PhD in Engineering while working on this project. Mr. Rubio, while working on doped-Ga2O3 for oxygen sensors, received extensive training on sensor materials fabrication, analytical characterization and sensor device integration. Finally, upon graduation, Dr. Rubio joined Intel as an Engineer. This is remarkable achievement and significant impact of this project since it is an example of URM recruitment, provide excellent opportunities for research and education, and finally mentor them to attain the highest degree and find suitable career in the STEM field. In addition to Dr. Rubio, the project work employed Mr. Anil Krishna Battu and Mr. Sandeep Manandhar, both at PhD level. Anton Pharr, one of the manufacturers of mechanical sensors and atomic force microscopes, hired Dr. Manadhar (recently graduated with a PhD). Dr. Manadhar receiving employment offer even before graduating is a testimony of the project broader impacts. Mr. Anil received the PhD internship at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory. Similar to Dr. Rubio, Mr. Cristian Orozco, Mr. Aldo Rubio, and Miss Marlyn Torres worked in this project. Both started as undergraduate students with a major in Mechanical Engineering at UTEP. This project allowed them to work in our research lab and trained on different sensor materials' fabrication and characterization. He received hands-on training on a wide variety of analytical capabilities for structural and electrical performance evaluation of Ga2O3-based oxygen sensors.Finally, upon graduation with MS degree, he was hired by DOD. Mr. Aldo Rubio is now a senior undergraduate; he plans to pursue MS. Miss Torres graduated and currently pursuing MS/PhD at Boston University. While these are just examples, the project indirectly made substantial impact on numerous students at UTEP.

The workshops/meetings/seminars presented at UTEP provided an opportunity for the local community and public to understand the importance of the importance of higher education and, more specifically, the need for expertise in the topical area of advanced sensors and actuators. In addition, from the success stories of URM  students, public awareness is improved and realization of the impact of higher education in society-development and ways to contribute to the economic-development of the region.
